questions.text: All of the following example of homopolysaccharides except:
questions.solution:
Polysaccharides (Glycans): Condensation products of >10 monosaccharides.

  • Homopolysaccharides: Composed of a single monosaccharide (e.g., starch, glycogen, cellulose).
  • Heteropolysaccharides: Composed of multiple types of monosaccharides (e.g., agar, mucopolysaccharides).
  • Starch: Glucose homopolymer in plants; contains amylose and amylopectin.
  • Agar: Seaweed-derived, used in bacterial culture, contains galactose and other sugars.
  • Cellulose: Major plant cell wall component; undigestible by humans.
  • Glycogen: Animal storage form of glucose, highly branched, found in liver and muscles.
  • Option A (Starch): The main dietary carbohydrate in plants, primarily composed of amylose and amylopectin, providing energy through its glucose polymer structure.
  • Option C (Cellulose): Structural polysaccharide in plants, indigestible by humans, so no role in energy storage.
  • Option D (Glycogen): Primary energy storage in animals, differs from agar and cellulose as it is readily accessible for metabolism.

Key takeaways: Homopolysaccharides are composed of a single type of monosaccharide (e.g., starch, glycogen), while heteropolysaccharides consist of two or more different monosaccharides (e.g., mucopolysaccharides, agar).

choices.text: It acts as a lubricant in the joints
It is present in the seminal fluid enabling sperm to entry into the ovum
It is a component of synaptic vesicles
It is made up of repeating unit of D-Glucoronic acid and N-acetyl-D-glucosamine

questions.text: All of the following are true about Hyaluronic acid, except
questions.solution:
Option A: Hyaluronic acid It is present in connective tissues, tendons, synovial fluid and vitreous humor. It serves as a lubricant in joint cavities.

Option B: Hyaluronidase enzyme (not hyaluronic acid) is present in the seminal fluid enabling sperm to entry into the ovum.

Hyaluronic acid is present as a gel around the ovum. It is cleared by hyaluronidase enzyme (present in seminal fluid), enabling entry of sperm into the ovum, so help in fertilization.

Option C: Hyaluronic acid is also present as component of synaptic vesicles.

Option D: It is composed of repeating units of D-Glucuronic acid and N-Acetyl D glucosamine held together by beta (1-3) glycosidic bond.

Key takeaways: Hyaluronic acid is a lubricant in connective tissues and synovial fluid, aids fertilization by being cleared by hyaluronidase, and consists of D-glucuronic acid and N-acetyl-D-glucosamine units linked by β(1-3) glycosidic bonds.

questions.text: Glucose and galactose are epimers to each other in reference to carbon no.
questions.solution:
• Epimers: Isomers differing in configuration at specific carbon atoms; mannose (C2) and galactose (C4) are significant epimers of glucose.
  • Alpha- and Beta-Anomers: The cyclic form of glucose (α and β anomers) arises from the reaction of its carbonyl group with an alcohol, with α-D-glucopyranose at 38% and β-D-glucopyranose at 62%.
  • Aldose-Ketose Isomerism: Fructose and glucose share the same molecular formula, but fructose has a ketone group at C2, while glucose has an aldehyde group at C1.

Key takeaways: Alpha- and beta-anomers are isomers of sugars differing at the anomeric carbon, with glucose predominantly as β-D-glucopyranose (62%) and fructose having a keto group at position 2, while glucose has an aldehyde group at position 1.

choices.text: Keratan sulphate has a role in maintaining the shape of eyeball
Heparin has an important role in to prevent intravascular clotting
Chondroitin sulphate contributes its role in cartilage to its compressibility and weight bearing capacity
Dermatan sulphate is present in heart valves and blood vessels also

questions.text: All of the following are true about heteropolysaccharides, except
questions.solution:
Option A: Keratan sulphate play role in maintaining corneal transparency. Dermatan sulphate has structural role in sclera and help in maintaining shape of eyeball.

Option B: Heparin is found in the granules of mast cells and also in liver, lung, and skin. It is an important anticoagulant. It is released into the blood from capillary walls by the action of lipoprotein lipase and it binds with factors IX and XI, but its most important interaction is with plasma antithrombin.

Option C: Chondroitin sulphate have role in compressibility of cartilage and weight bearing capacity.

Option D: Dermatan sulfate has a widespread distribution in tissues, and is the main GAG in skin. It is also present in blood vessels, heart valves, cornea, sclera etc. Evidence suggests it may play a part in blood coagulation, wound repair, and resistance to infection.

Key takeaways: Keratan sulphate maintains corneal transparency, while dermatan sulphate provides structural support in the sclera and helps maintain the shape of the eyeball.

choices.text: It generates NADH2 in HMP shunt
The products of the HMP shunt are used for DNA & RNA synthesis
The products of the HMP shunt are used to maintain RBC membrane integrity
The reactions occur in two phases: oxidative phase and non-oxidative phase

questions.text: All of the following statements about HMP shunt are true, except
questions.solution:
Pentose Phosphate Pathway (PPP): An alternative glucose metabolism route providing NADPH and ribose for biosynthesis and nucleotide synthesis.

Functions:

  • NADPH Production: Vital for fatty acid and steroid synthesis and maintaining reduced glutathione.
  • Ribose Synthesis: Essential for DNA and RNA formation.

Oxidative Phase: Generates NADPH.

Non-Oxidative Phase: Produces ribose precursors.

Red Blood Cell Protection: NADPH maintains RBC membrane integrity; defects in glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase can lead to hemolytic anemia under oxidative stress.

  • Option A: Generates NADPH, not NADH2.
  • Option B: Produces ribose for nucleic acid synthesis.
  • Option C: NADPH maintains reduced glutathione, protecting RBCs from oxidative damage; critical in preventing hemolysis.
  • Option D: Comprises two phases: oxidative (producing NADPH) and non-oxidative (generating ribose precursors).

Key takeaways: The pentose phosphate pathway is an alternative glucose metabolism route that generates NADPH for fatty acid and steroid synthesis, maintains reduced glutathione for antioxidant activity, and produces ribose for nucleotide and nucleic acid synthesis.

questions.text: Which of the following step of krebs cycle is an example of substrate level phosphorylation?
questions.solution:
Option A: Isocitrate to oxalosuccinate reaction is catalyzed by enzyme Isocitrate dehydrogenase, which produces NADH2, which is via ETC produces 2.5 ATPs. Not directly produces ATP.

Option B: Oxalosuccinate to alpha-ketogluatarate is also catalyzed by same enzyme Isocitrate dehydrogenase.

Isocitrate dehydrogenase convert Isocitrate to alpha ketoglutarate, oxalosuccinate is an intermediate produce in this conversation.

Option C: Alpha-ketogluatarate to Succinyl CoA reaction is catalyzed by alpha ketoglutarate dehydrogenase enzyme, which produces NADH2, which is via ETC produces 2.5 ATPs. Not directly produces ATP.

Option D: Succinyl CoA to Succinate reaction is catalyzed by succinyl CoA synthetase (succinate thiokinase). This will phosphorylate GDP to GTP, later GTP can be converted to ATP. High energy phosphate is directly trapped here & produces GTP, so it is an example of substrate level phosphorylation.

Key takeaways: Substrate-level phosphorylation is the direct production of ATP from ADP by transferring a phosphate group from a high-energy substrate molecule during cellular respiration or fermentation.

questions.text: Match the following enzyme deficiency and related disease
questions.solution:
Option A: Pompe's disease occurs due to defect in lysosomal acid maltase (α1 → 4 and α1 → 6 glucosidase) enzyme. It is characterized by accumulation of glycogen in lysosomes: juvenile-onset variant, muscle hypotonia, death from heart failure by age 2; adult-onset variant, muscle dystrophy.

Option B: Limit dextrinosis (Forbes or Cori disease) occurs due to defect in liver and muscle debranching enzyme. It results in fasting hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly in infancy, accumulation of characteristic branched polysaccharide (limit dextrin) and muscle weakness.

Option C: Andersen disease (also known as amylopectinosis) occurs due to defect in branching enzyme (alpha (1-4) transferase). It is characterized by hepatosplenomegaly and accumulation of polysaccharide with few branch points. Such child usually dies before 5 year of age due to heart or liver failure.

Option D: A defect in muscle glycogen phosphorylase (Myophosphorylase deficiency) results in McArdle syndrome. It results in poor exercise tolerance; muscle glycogen abnormally high (2.5-4%); blood lactate very low after exercise.

Key takeaways:

choices.text: It occurs due to deficiency of galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase
All the symptoms of the galactosemia are reversible
Congenital cataract is seen commonly in this disease
Galactosemia is treated simply by galactose free diet

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about galactosemia, except
questions.solution:
• Definition: Galactosemia is the inability to metabolize galactose due to defects in specific enzymes.
  • Causes:
    • Enzymatic Defects: Caused by inherited defects in Galactokinase, Galactose-1-Phosphate Uridyl Transferase, or UDP-galactose 4-epimerase, with uridyl transferase deficiency being the most common.
  • Consequences:
    • Galactitol Formation: Galactose is metabolized by aldose reductase into galactitol, leading to cataracts if it accumulates in the lens.
    • Toxic Accumulation: Uridyl transferase deficiency results in the accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate, depleting the liver of inorganic phosphate and leading to irreversible symptoms such as liver failure and mental deterioration.
  • Management:
    • Galactose-Free Diet: A galactose-free diet can control symptoms; however, individuals can still convert glucose to UDP-galactose due to adequate epimerase levels, allowing for normal growth and development despite the dietary restrictions.
  • Option B & C: Focus on consequences of galactose accumulation but not on genetic causes or dietary management.
  • Option D: Discusses dietary management without addressing the enzymatic deficiencies leading to galactosemia.
  • Option A is correct as it identifies the specific enzyme deficiencies causing galactosemia.

Key takeaways: Galactose metabolism defects lead to cataracts, liver failure, and mental deterioration due to galactitol and galactose-1-phosphate accumulation.

questions.text: All of the following inhibits pyruvate kinase enzyme in glycolysis, except
questions.solution:
Irreversible Reactions: Three key irreversible reactions are present in glycolysis.

Key Enzymes:

  • Hexokinase/Glucokinase: Catalyzes the phosphorylation of glucose.
  • Phosphofructo Kinase: Key regulatory step in glycolysis.
  • Pyruvate Kinase: Catalyzes the conversion of phosphoenolpyruvate to pyruvate.

Regulatory Factors:

  • Inhibitors:
    • Glucagon: Inhibits pyruvate kinase.
    • ATP: High levels indicate sufficient energy, inhibiting pyruvate kinase.
    • cAMP: Activates pathways that inhibit glycolysis.
  • Activator:
    • Fructose-1,6-bisphosphate: Activates pyruvate kinase, promoting glycolysis.

Option A, Option B & Option C: Glucagon, ATP & cAMP inhibits pyruvate kinase enzymes.

Option D: Fructose-1,6 biphosphate activates pyruvate kinase enzyme.

Key takeaways: Fructose-1,6-bisphosphate activates pyruvate kinase by enhancing its catalytic activity, while glucagon, ATP, and cAMP inhibit the enzyme, reducing glycolysis. This regulation ensures efficient energy production and balance based on cellular needs.

questions.text: Which receptor transports glucose entry into liver cells
questions.solution:
Option A: GLUT 1 help in glucose uptake in brain, kidney, colon, placenta, erythrocytes.

Option B: GLUT 2 help in rapid uptake or release of glucose in liver, pancreatic β cell, small intestine, kidney.

Option C: GLUT 3 help in glucose uptake in brain, kidney, placenta.

Option D: GLUT 4 involved in glucose uptake in heart and skeletal muscle, adipose tissue. It is stimulated by Insulin.

Key takeaways:

questions.text: In glycogenesis, glucose is added to glycogen primarily in the form of:
questions.solution:
Glycogenin Role:

  • Initiates glycogen synthesis by being glucosylated on a specific tyrosine residue using UDP Glucose (UDPGlc).
  • Transfers seven additional glucose residues to form a glycogen primer.

Glycogen Synthase:

  • Uses the glycogen primer as a substrate to add glucose residues.
  • Catalyzes the formation of a glycosidic bond between C-1 of the glucose from UDPGlc and C-4 of a terminal glucose residue in glycogen, releasing UDP.

Glucose Addition:

  • Glucose is incorporated into glycogen in the form of UDP Glucose.

So Option C is correct option.

Key takeaways: Glycogen synthesis begins with glycogenin, which uses UDP-glucose to form a primer that glycogen synthase then extends by adding glucose units.

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme of glycogenolysis is absent in muscles?
questions.solution:
Glycogen Phosphorylase (Option A):

  • Function: Catalyzes the rate-limiting step in glycogenolysis.
  • Action: Cleaves 1 → 4 linkages in glycogen, yielding glucose-1-phosphate.

Phosphoglucomutase (Option B):

  • Function: Converts glucose-6-phosphateto glucose-1-phosphate.
  • Mechanism: Achieves this through isomerization.

Glycogen Synthase (Option C):

  • Role: Key enzyme in glycogenesis.
  • Process: Forms glycosidic bonds between UDPGlc and terminal glucose residues.
  • Outcome: Liberates UDP; present in muscle and liver

Glucose-6-Phosphatase (Option D):

  • Function: Converts glucose-6-phosphateto glucose.
  • Location: Found in liver and kidneybut absent in muscle, preventing glucose export into the bloodstream.

Key takeaways: Glycogen phosphorylase catalyzes glycogen breakdown to glucose-1-phosphate, while glycogen synthase synthesizes glycogen from glucose, and glucose-6-phosphatase converts glucose-6-phosphate to glucose, which muscle cannot export due to the absence of the enzyme.

questions.text: Which of the following is an allosteric inhibitor of pyruvate dehydrogenase complex (PDC)?
questions.solution:
Oxidative Decarboxylation:

  • Pyruvate converts to acetyl-CoA via a multienzyme complex located in the inner mitochondrial membrane.

Inhibition by Products (Option A):

  • Acetyl-CoA and NADH inhibit the activity of pyruvate dehydrogenase (PDH).

Activation by Substrates (Options B & C):

  • NADH and pyruvate activate PDH, promoting the conversion to acetyl-CoA.

Regulation by ATP (Option D):

  • Covalent modification: ATP activates a kinase that phosphorylates PDH, reducing its activity.
  • Increased ratios of [ATP]/[ADP], [acetyl-CoA]/[CoA], and [NADH]/[NADH] stimulate kinase activity.

Phosphorylation and Dephosphorylation:

  • Phosphorylation(by kinase) of three serine residues reduces PDH activity.
  • Dephosphorylation(by phosphatase) increases PDH activity.

Metabolic Context:

  • During fasting, higher nonesterified fatty acids decrease active PDH, conserving carbohydrates.
  • In adipose tissue, insulin activates PDH, allowing glucose to provide acetyl-CoA for lipogenesis.

Key takeaways: Pyruvate dehydrogenase (PDH) activity is decreased by phosphorylation in high ATP/ADP, acetyl-CoA/CoA, and NADH/NAD+ ratios, inhibiting glycolysis during fasting and fatty acid oxidation, while insulin activates PDH for lipogenesis in adipose tissue.

questions.text: Which of the following molecules allosterically activates phosphofructokinase-1 (PFK-1) in glycolysis?
questions.solution:
Irreversible Reactions:

  • Three key reactions in glycolysis are physiologically irreversible:
    • Hexokinase/Glucokinase
    • Phosphofructokinase (PFK)
    • Pyruvate Kinase

Major Regulation Points:

  • These reactions serve as major regulatory sites for glycolysis due to their exergonic nature.

Inhibition by ATP (Options A & B):

  • Phosphofructokinase (PFK)is significantly inhibited by ATP at normal intracellular concentrations.
  • The inhibition is relieved by 5′AMP, which increases as ADP accumulates, indicating a need for enhanced glycolysis.

Inhibition by NADH and Citrate (Options C & D):

  • NADH and citrate also inhibit PFK, signaling sufficient energy and metabolic intermediates, thus reducing glycolytic activity.

Key takeaways: The three irreversible reactions in glycolysis, catalyzed by hexokinase, phosphofructokinase, and pyruvate kinase, are key regulatory points, with phosphofructokinase inhibited by ATP and activated by 5′AMP, signaling the need for increased glycolysis as ADP accumulates.

choices.text: Reduced reliance on glycolysis for ATP production
Enhanced lactate production even in the presence of oxygen

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic feature of the Warburg effect in cancer cells?
questions.solution:
Mitochondrial Defects (Option A):

  • Defects in the mitochondrial respiratory chain lead to decreased oxidative phosphorylation, impairing efficient ATP production.

Glycolytic Dependence (Option B):

  • Cancer cells rely more heavily on glycolysis for ATP production, compensating for the reduced efficiency of aerobic respiration.

Lactate Production (Option C):

  • There is enhanced lactate production even in the presence of oxygen, a phenomenon known as aerobic glycolysis or the Warburg effect.

Increased Glucose Uptake (Option D):

  • Cancer cells exhibit increased glucose uptake to support their high glycolytic activity, facilitating rapid proliferation in hypoxic conditions typical of tumors.

Key takeaways:

  • Warburg's findings suggest that mitochondrial defects in cancer cells lead to increased reliance on glycolysis, resulting in elevated lactate production and enhanced glucose uptake, contributing to tumor growth even in oxygen-rich environments.

questions.text: Which is the main product of the oxidative phase of the HMP shunt?
questions.solution:
Alternative Metabolic Route:

  • The HMP (Pentose Phosphate) pathway is an alternative route for glucose metabolism, not generating ATP.

Major Functions:

  • Formation of NADPH: Essential for fatty acid and steroid synthesis and maintaining reduced glutathione for antioxidant activity.
  • Synthesis of Ribose: Critical for nucleotide and nucleic acid formation.

Phases of the Pathway:

  • Oxidative Phase: Generates NADPH.
  • Non-Oxidative Phase: Produces ribose precursors.

Key Misconceptions:

  • Does not generate NADHor FADH2(Option A & C).
  • Does not lead to ATP formation(Option D).

Role in Red Blood Cells:

  • The PPP is the sole source of NADPH for the reduction of oxidized glutathione, vital for protecting erythrocytes from oxidative damage.

Genetic Defects:

  • Defects in glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase are common, particularly in Mediterranean and Afro-Caribbean populations, leading to hemolytic anemia under oxidative stress.
  • The mutation offers a survival advantage against malaria, illustrating a link between genetic polymorphisms and environmental pressures.

Key takeaways: Defects in glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD), which impair NADPH production, primarily affect males due to X-linked inheritance, and can lead to hemolytic anemia under oxidative stress, with a distribution linked to malaria resistance.

choices.text: Insulin stimulates glucose uptake into cells
Insulin activates glucagon secretion from the pancreas

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the role of insulin in carbohydrate metabolism is correct?
questions.solution:
1. Hormonal Production:
    • Glucagon: Produced by α cells of the pancreatic islets in response to hypoglycemia(Option C).
    • Insulin: Produced by β cells of the pancreatic islets in response to hyperglycemia.
  2. Functions of Glucagon:
    • Promotes glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis in the liver (Option A).
    • Activates glycogen phosphorylase for glycogen breakdown.
    • Enhances gluconeogenesis from amino acids and lactate.
    • Acts via the generation of cAMP to raise blood glucose levels.
  3. Functions of Insulin:
    • Stimulates glucose uptake into cells (Option B).
    • Increases metabolic flux through glycolysis, the citric acid cycle, and ATP generation.
    • Inhibits ATP-sensitive K+ channels, leading to increased Ca2+ influx and insulin secretion.
    • Enhances glucose transport into adipose tissue and muscle via GLUT 4.
  4. Regulatory Actions:
    • Insulin lowers blood glucose immediately and promotes long-term glucose uptake by regulating enzymes involved in glycolysis, glycogenesis, and gluconeogenesis.
    • Epinephrine and norepinephrine inhibit insulin release, counteracting its effects.
  5. Glycolysis and Insulin:
    • Insulin does not inhibit glycolysis(Option D); rather, it promotes glucose metabolism.

Key takeaways:

Insulin is released by pancreatic β cells in response to hyperglycemia, increasing ATP levels that inhibit K+ channels, leading to Ca2+ influx and insulin exocytosis, while it lowers blood glucose by enhancing glucose uptake via GLUT 4 in tissues and regulating metabolic enzymes in the liver.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is characterized by impaired glucose uptake due to insulin resistance?
questions.solution:
Type I Diabetes Mellitus (IDDM):

  • Characterized by impaired glucose tolerance due to decreased insulin secretion.
  • Results from progressive destruction of pancreatic β-islet cells (Option A).

Type II Diabetes Mellitus (NIDDM):

  • Characterized by impaired glucose tolerance due to insulin resistance (Option B).
  • Associated with obesity and can lead to hyperlipidemia, atherosclerosis, coronary heart disease, and overt diabetes.
  • Conditions causing insulin resistance can include liver damage, infections, certain drugs, and hormonal imbalances.

Hypoglycemia:

  • An excess of insulin can lead to hypoglycemia, causing symptoms like convulsions and potentially death if untreated (Option C).

Complications in Type I Diabetes:

  • In poorly controlled Type I diabetes, patients may become hyperglycemic due to:
    • Lack of insulin for glucose uptake.
    • Increased gluconeogenesis from amino acids due to elevated glucagon
  • Increased lipolysis leads to non-esterified fatty acids that serve as substrates for (option D)
  • Lack of oxaloacetate (from insufficient glucose) impairs the utilization of ketone bodies, potentially leading to severe ketoacidosis.

Key takeaways: Type 2 diabetes mellitus is characterized by impaired glucose uptake due to insulin resistance, leading to elevated blood glucose levels despite the presence of insulin.

questions.text: During prolonged fasting, which process primarily supplies glucose to the bloodstream to maintain blood glucose levels?
questions.solution:
1. A) Glycogenolysis:
    • Definition: Breakdown of glycogen into glucose.
    • Function: Maintains blood glucose levels during fasting.
    • Details:
      • Liver glycogen serves as a glucose reserve, depleting after 12-18 hours of fasting.
      • Muscle glycogen provides glucose-1-phosphate for glycolysis but does not yield free glucose directly due to the absence of glucose-6-phosphatase.
      • Pyruvate from glycolysis in muscle can convert to alanine for gluconeogenesis in the liver.
  1. B) Glycolysis:
    • Definition: Breakdown of glucose into pyruvate (aerobic) or lactate (anaerobic).
    • Function: Produces energy for cellular functions.
    • Importance: Essential for energy production during high-demand states.
  2. C) Gluconeogenesis:
    • Definition: Synthesis of glucose from non-carbohydrate sources.
    • Major Substrates: Glucogenic amino acids, lactate, glycerol, and propionate.
    • Tissues Involved: Primarily the liver and kidneys; kidneys can significantly contribute to glucose production during fasting.
    • Role in Fasting: After overnight fasting, both glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis contribute to blood glucose; gluconeogenesis becomes increasingly important as glycogen stores deplete.
  3. D) Lipogenesis:
    • Definition: Synthesis of fat.
    • Condition: Occurs during the fed state, not during fasting.
    • Role: Stores excess energy as fat for later use.

Conclusion:

Key takeaways:

questions.text: All of the following are coenzymes of PDH complex, except
questions.solution:
Pyruvate Decarboxylation:

  • Process: Pyruvate undergoes oxidative decarboxylation to form acetyl-CoA.
  • Catalyst: This reaction is catalyzed by the pyruvate dehydrogenase (PDH) complex, located in the inner mitochondrial membrane.

Coenzymes Required:

  • Vitamin B1 (Thiamine): Required as thiamin diphosphate (TPP) (Option A).
  • Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin): Required as flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD) (Option B).
  • Vitamin B3 (Niacin): Required as nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD) (Option A).
  • Vitamin B5 (Coenzyme A): Required as coenzyme A (CoASH).
  • Lipoamide: Also serves as a crucial coenzyme in the PDH complex.

Non-Required Coenzyme:

  • Biotin: Not used as a coenzyme in the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex, making Option D correct.

Key takeaways: Pyruvate is converted to acetyl-CoA by the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex, which requires coenzymes including vitamins B1, B2, B3, B5, and lipoamide.

questions.text: In individuals with fructose intolerance, ingestion of fructose-containing foods can lead to accumulation of which toxic intermediate?
questions.solution:
Hereditary Fructose Intolerance:

Condition Overview:

  • Cause: Hereditary fructose intolerance is due to the absence of aldolase B, an enzyme that cleaves fructose-1-phosphate.
  • Consequence: This leads to an increase in fructose-1-phosphate levels in the body.

Symptoms:

  • Profound Hypoglycemia: Characterized by low blood sugar levels.
  • Vomiting: Occurs after the consumption of fructose or sucrose (which yields fructose upon digestion).

Dietary Management:

  • Recommended Diet: Diets low in fructose, sorbitol, and sucrose are beneficial for managing the condition.

Biochemical Consequences:

  • Hypoglycemia Despite Glycogen Reserves: Fructose-1-phosphate and fructose-1,6-bisphosphate inhibit liver glycogen phosphorylase, leading to reduced glucose release from glycogen stores.
  • Inorganic Phosphate Sequestration: This process depletes ATP levels and can lead to hyperuricemia (increased uric acid levels).

So Option A is correct option.

Key takeaways: Hereditary fructose intolerance and fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase deficiency cause hypoglycemia despite high glycogen reserves due to the allosteric inhibition of liver glycogen phosphorylase by fructose-1-phosphate and 1,6-bisphosphate, leading to ATP depletion and hyperuricemia.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is deficient in hereditary fructose intolerance?
questions.solution:
Hereditary Fructose Intolerance:

  • Cause: Absence of aldolase B, an enzyme that cleaves fructose-1-phosphate.
  • Symptoms:
    • Profound Hypoglycemia: Occurs after the intake of fructose or sucrose.
    • Vomiting: Triggered by the consumption of fructose-containing foods.
  • Dietary Management: Low-fructose, low-sorbitol, and low-sucrose diets are recommended.

Essential Fructosuria:

  • Cause: Lack of hepatic fructokinase, the enzyme responsible for phosphorylating fructose.
  • Symptoms: This condition is benign and asymptomatic; individuals can often lead normal lives without intervention.

So Option C is correct option.

Key takeaways: Hereditary fructose intolerance results from aldolase B deficiency, causing severe hypoglycemia and vomiting after fructose consumption, while a lack of hepatic fructokinase leads to essential fructosuria, a benign condition; both require diets low in fructose, sorbitol, and sucrose.

choices.text: Glucuronic acid serves as a precursor for Ascorbic acid (vitamin C)
Glucuronic acid conjugates with drugs, toxins, and other xenobiotics through glucuronidation
Barbiturates decreases the pathway of glucuronic acid
L-Gulonolactone oxidase is absent in the human beings hence ascorbic acid cannot be synthesized by human beings

questions.text: Identify the incorrect sentence regarding glucuronic acid pathway
questions.solution:
• The glucuronic acid pathway is an alternative oxidative pathway for glucose.
  • Similar to the pentose phosphate pathway, it does not produce ATP.

Conversion Processes:

  • In the liver, glucose is converted into:
    • Glucuronic Acid
    • Ascorbic Acid(Vitamin C, not synthesized in humans)
    • Pentoses

Details on Reactions:

  • Option A & D:
    • Glucuronate is reduced to l-gulonate, which is a direct precursor to ascorbate in certain animals.
    • Humans and some other species cannot synthesize ascorbic acid due to the absence of the enzyme l-gulonolactone oxidase.
  • Option B:
    • UDP-glucuronate serves as a source of glucuronate for:
      • Incorporation into proteoglycans.
      • Conjugation reactions with substrates like steroid hormones, bilirubin, and various drugs, which are excreted as glucuronide conjugates.
    • Option C:
      • Substances like barbiturates, antipyrine, and aminopyrine enhance the uronic acid pathway, increasing the availability of glucuronate for conjugation purposes.

Key takeaways: The glucuronic acid pathway converts glucose to glucuronic acid and pentoses without producing ATP, with UDP-glucuronate providing glucuronate for conjugation of substances like drugs and steroids, while certain drugs enhance glucuronate availability for this purpose.

questions.text: Essential pentosuria is characterized by the excessive excretion of:
questions.solution:
Essential Pentosuria:

  1. Definition:
    • Essential Pentosuria is an inborn error of metabolism characterized by the excretion of L-xylulose in urine.
  2. Pathway Overview:
    • L-xylulose is converted to D-xylulose by two enzymes:
      • Xylitol dehydrogenase
      • Xylulose reductase
    • A deficiency in either enzyme results in pentosuria, but xylulose reductase deficiency is the most common cause.
  3. Diagnostic Features:
    • L-xylulose is detectable in urine, giving a positive Benedict's test.
  4. Influencing Factors:
    • Certain medications, such as barbiturates and aminopyrine, can induce the uronic acid pathway, increasing xylulosuria in affected individuals.
  5. Clinical Significance:
    • The condition is harmless and should be differentiated from diabetes mellitus, which can present with similar symptoms.
  6. Garrod's Tetrad:
    • Pentosuria is one of the conditions included in Garrod's tetrad, which consists of:
      • Albinism
      • Alkaptonuria
      • Cystinuria
      • Pentosuria
  1. Alimentary Pentosuria:
    • Pentosuria can also occur after consuming large quantities of fruits, particularly pears, which are high in pentoses.

So Option D is correct.

Key takeaways: Essential pentosuria is an inborn error of metabolism marked by excessive excretion of L-xylulose due to a deficiency in xylulose reductase, resulting in a positive Benedict's test and being harmless.

questions.text: Which enzyme is essential for this reaction
questions.solution:
Option A:

  • Lactate Dehydrogenase converts pyruvate to lactate.
  • Function: Occurs during anaerobic glycolysis to regenerate NAD+.

Option B:

  • Enolase converts 2-phosphoglycerate to phosphoenolpyruvate (PEP).
  • Function: Involved in aerobic glycolysis; this reaction is part of the energy production pathway.

Option C:

  • Pyruvate Kinase converts phosphoenolpyruvate (PEP) to pyruvate.
  • Function: An irreversible step in glycolysis, playing a key role in energy production.

Option D:

  • Phosphoenolpyruvate Carboxykinase (PEPCK) catalyzes the decarboxylation and phosphorylation of oxaloacetate to phosphoenolpyruvate (PEP).
  • Function: This reaction occurs in gluconeogenesis, helping to synthesize glucose from non-carbohydrate sources.

Key takeaways: Pyruvate kinase catalyzes the irreversible conversion of phosphoenolpyruvate to pyruvate in glycolysis, generating ATP through substrate-level phosphorylation. This enzyme is regulated by factors such as fructose-1,6-bisphosphate (activator) and ATP (inhibitor), influencing energy production and metabolite flow.
